abstract.p: Bonneville Environmental Foundation vice president Rob Harman letter on June 25 article about consumers' purchase of environmental offsets

block.p: Re ''A New Way to Ask, 'How Green Is My Conscience?' '' (June 25), which described consumers' purchase of environmental offsets, to make up for the pollution caused by the events of everyday life:
As the article said, the challenge for consumers wishing to reduce their ''carbon footprint'' is to understand how much their dollars help the environment.
Re ''A New Way to Ask, 'How Green Is My Conscience?' '' (June 25), which described consumers' purchase of environmental offsets, to make up for the pollution caused by the events of everyday life:
As the article said, the challenge for consumers wishing to reduce their ''carbon footprint'' is to understand how much their dollars help the environment.

The carbon problem is an energy problem. The solution is to increase the amount of secure, domestic, renewable energy entering the grid. Planting trees may be a low-cost, short-term way to reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, but it does nothing to address the underlying problem: an overreliance on fossil fuels.
The writer is a vice president of the Bonneville Environmental Foundation, which sells offsets generated from renewable energy projects.
